item.title: Availability bias
item.description: Relevant Notes Notes Believing what’s convenient Believing what we connect most to ourself Highlights Availability bias is the tendency to rely on information that‚Äôs readily available, instead of what‚Äôs actually more relevant to the situation.

item.title: Becoming a better ally with MakeSense
item.description: Relevant Notes privilege References Notes Practice tips Educate yourself It’s your burden, no one else’s Look up on different readings to take up the initiative to learn about different people Invisible Women by Caroline Perez #book-recs Don’t be hard on yourself Listen More than you talk active-listening, reflective listening Best way we can learn how we can help Nuances of privilege If you felt like you had adequate access to healthy food growing up If you feel comfortable being emotionally expressive/ open If your parents or guardians attended college if you studied the culture or the history of your ancesotrs in elementary school if one of your parents have never been laid off or unemployed against their choice If you have enver taken our loans for your education Step back Self-reflect Circle of accountability Speak out!

item.title: Boundaries as invitation rather than limitation

item.title: collector-fallacy
item.description: Relevant Notes productivity learning-in-public Notes Fallacy: As you collect, your knowledge grows But what actually happens is that you don’t process and digest these notes Although a lengthy process, take time to convert these notes into ones you actually learn, know, and digest–you don’t learn just by highlighting What we need to focus on is DEVELOP knowledge, not connect Highlights The Collector‚Äôs Fallacy ‚Ä¢ Zettelkasten Method The worst we could do is to pile up copies until the stack grows intimidatingly high, until it becomes unmanageable.

item.title: Confirmation Bias
item.description: Relevant Notes Notes Highlights On the other hand, confirmation bias is at play when you seek out information that fits in with how you already see the world.

item.title: how-to-apologzize
item.description: Tags: Relevant Notes leadership learning-thinking-communicating Notes Apologizing to a colleague Make it personal: Private > public Just admit the mistake, don’t try to defend yourself/ make yourself look better Formula Admit the mistake Connect with emotion Offer a solution Highlights Apologies are never easy ‚Äì especially in the workplace1 ‚ÄúI note that the event took place in front of other people, but I think the person who messed up should first offer a private apology because an apology should focus on the needs of the aggrieved person, and that person might not want a public apology.

item.title: Typography inclusivity & accessibility
item.description: Relevant Notes References Webflow 101 crash course | Webflow University Notes Considerations Font legibility Ultra thin fonts are difficult to read especially as paragraph Uneven weight distribution Text alignment Uneven rag in typography, example in centered text Alt caps All caps has more cognitive load Consider use when text is too long Underlines Standard: It is a hyperlink Consider something else for emphasis Contrast Use contrast checkers Higher contrast
